bibl.title: Military Orders for Robert P. Cooke, February 1, 1901 [selected page]

div1.p: Special Orders #27 orders Cooke to Camp Mackenzie for duty. [Courtesy of the National Archives and Records Administration]

div1.head: Military Orders for Robert P. Cooke, February 1, 1901 [selected page]
div1.p:
HEADQUARTERS DEPARTMENT OF CUBA,
Havana, February 1, 1901.

1. Acting Assistant Surgeon Robert P. Cooke, U. S. Army,
having completed the duty assigned him in paragraph 5,
Special Orders No. 5, series of 1900, these Headquarters,
will proceed to Camp Mackenzie, near Puerto Príncipe,
Cuba, and report to the commanding officer for duty.
The travel enjoined is necessary for the public service.

2. Acting Assistant SurgeonMarion B. McMillan, U. S.
Army, is hereby relieved from further duty at Camp Mac-
kenzie, Puerto Príncipe, Cuba, and will proceed to Holguín,
Cuba, reporting to the commanding officer for duty as as-
sistant to the surgeon.
The travel enjoined is necessary for the public service.

3. Private Richard Ebers, Hospital Corps, U. S. Army, is
hereby relieved from duty at the Medical Supply Depot,
Havana, Cuba, and will proceed to Columbia Barracks,
Cuba, reporting upon arrival to the commanding officer for
duty at that post.

The Quartermaster's Department will furnish the neces-
sary transportation.
The travel enjoined is necessary for the public service.

4. Private Aaron Freeman, Hospital Corps, U. S. Army,
is hereby relieved from duty at Camp Mackenzie, Puerto
Príncipe, Cuba, and will proceed to Morro Castle, Santiago,
Cuba, reporting upon arrival to the commanding officer for
duty at that post.

The Quartermaster's Department will furnish the neces-
sary transportation.
The travel enjoined is necessary for the public service.

5. Upon the recommendation of his battery and post
commander, the unexecuted portion of sentence imposed
by general court-martial in the case of private Thomas Baynes,
battery I, 2d Artillery, as promulgated in paragraph 6,
Special Orders No. 182, series of 1900, Headquarters Divi-
sion of Cuba, is hereby remitted.

6. Private Linwood E. Farish, battery M, 2d U. S. Artil-
lery, having been tried by a general court-martial convened
at Santa Clara Battery, Havana, Cuba, and found guilty of
disobedience of orders of a commissioned officer, to the pre-
judice of good order and military discipline, in violation of
the 62d Article of War (one previous conviction), was sen-
